questions.question: What is the structure of the First Conditional?
Which sentence is an example of the First Conditional?
choices: If it rains, I will stay at home.
If it rained, I would stay at home.
If it had rained, I would have stayed at home.
If it rains, I would stay at home.
questions.answer: If it rains, I will stay at home.

questions.question: What type of situation does the First Conditional describe?
Which modal verb can replace 'will' in the First Conditional?
What tense is used in the 'if clause' of the First Conditional?
Which sentence is NOT in the First Conditional?
choices: If you study hard, you will pass the exam.
If it snows, we'll go skiing.
If I had money, I would buy a car.
If she arrives early, we can start the meeting.
questions.answer: If I had money, I would buy a car.

questions.question: What is the function of 'if' in the First Conditional?
Which word can be used instead of 'if' in the First Conditional?
How do you form the negative in the 'if clause' of the First Conditional?
Which sentence shows the correct use of 'unless' in the First Conditional?
choices: Unless it rains, we'll go to the beach.
Unless it rains, we go to the beach.
Unless it will rain, we'll go to the beach.
Unless it would rain, we'll go to the beach.
questions.answer: Unless it rains, we'll go to the beach.

questions.question: What is the meaning of 'unless' in the First Conditional?
Which sentence shows the correct word order in the First Conditional?
choices: If will rain, I stay at home.
If it rain, I'll stay at home.
If it rains, I'll stay at home.
If it rains, I stay at home will.
questions.answer: If it rains, I'll stay at home.

questions.question: What is the function of 'will' in the First Conditional?
Which modal verb expresses the highest degree of certainty in the First Conditional?
How can you express a command or instruction using the First Conditional?
choices: Use the imperative in the result clause
Use 'have to' in the result clause
questions.answer: Use the imperative in the result clause

questions.question: Which sentence is an example of a First Conditional with an imperative in the result clause?
choices: If it rains, we'll stay inside.
If it rains, we would stay inside.

questions.question: What type of verb form is used after 'will' in the First Conditional?
Which sentence shows the correct use of 'may' in the First Conditional?
choices: If it rains, I may stay at home.
If it rains, I may stayed at home.
If it may rain, I will stay at home.
If it rained, I may stay at home.
questions.answer: If it rains, I may stay at home.

questions.question: What is the difference between 'when' and 'if' in conditional sentences?
choices: 'When' is used for certainties, 'if' for possibilities
'If' is used for certainties, 'when' for possibilities
There is no difference; they are interchangeable
'When' is only used in the past, 'if' in the future
questions.answer: 'When' is used for certainties, 'if' for possibilities

questions.question: Which sentence is NOT a correct use of the First Conditional?
choices: If you need help, call me.
When the sun sets, it will get cooler.
If I won the lottery, I will buy a house.
Unless you hurry, you'll miss the train.
questions.answer: If I won the lottery, I will buy a house.
